values.description: The Optitrack code revealed a timeout bug in HaptixGUIPlugin that prevented keyboard teleop from working. This pull request changes HaptixGUIPlugin to retry the first `getDeviceInfo` call a few times before giving up.
values.title: added better timeout logic to HaptixGUIPlugin

summary.raw: The Optitrack code revealed a timeout bug in HaptixGUIPlugin that prevented keyboard teleop from working. This pull request changes HaptixGUIPlugin to retry the first `getDeviceInfo` call a few times before giving up.
summary.html: The Optitrack code revealed a timeout bug in HaptixGUIPlugin that prevented keyboard teleop from working. This pull request changes HaptixGUIPlugin to retry the first getDeviceInfo call a few times before giving up.

values.reason: No longer need, the fix for this apparent bug happened in haptix-comm

values.description:
Companion to [haptix-comm PR#26](#!/osrf/haptix-comm/pull-request/26/implemented-hx_readsensors/diff). You can use the hx_sensor example in that PR to read the output of this new callback as delivered through ign-transport.

This PR adds a Read callback to HaptixControlPlugin which will respond to the new haptix-comm command `hx_readsensors`.

It also adds a call to `hx_readsensors` to `HaptixGUIPlugin::PollSensors`, which fixes a "controller fighting" problem observed by Heather and Carlos.
values.title: Added read sensor callback to HaptixControlPlugin

summary.raw:
Companion to [haptix-comm PR#26](#!/osrf/haptix-comm/pull-request/26/implemented-hx_readsensors/diff). You can use the hx_sensor example in that PR to read the output of this new callback as delivered through ign-transport.

This PR adds a Read callback to HaptixControlPlugin which will respond to the new haptix-comm command `hx_readsensors`.

It also adds a call to `hx_readsensors` to `HaptixGUIPlugin::PollSensors`, which fixes a "controller fighting" problem observed by Heather and Carlos.
summary.html:
Companion to haptix-comm PR#26. You can use the hx_sensor example in that PR to read the output of this new callback as delivered through ign-transport.

This PR adds a Read callback to HaptixControlPlugin which will respond to the new haptix-comm command hx_readsensors.

It also adds a call to hx_readsensors to HaptixGUIPlugin::PollSensors, which fixes a "controller fighting" problem observed by Heather and Carlos.

values.description: one of the differences between gazebo/haptix branch and gazebo5 is the presence of a subscriber to a QtKey event in GlWidget in order to receive key presses in the control plugin. This is kind of a hack, so I rewrote some of handsim in order not to rely on this subscriber.
values.title: Remove QtKey subscriber from HaptixControlPlugin

summary.raw: one of the differences between gazebo/haptix branch and gazebo5 is the presence of a subscriber to a QtKey event in GlWidget in order to receive key presses in the control plugin. This is kind of a hack, so I rewrote some of handsim in order not to rely on this subscriber.
summary.html: one of the differences between gazebo/haptix branch and gazebo5 is the presence of a subscriber to a QtKey event in GlWidget in order to receive key presses in the control plugin. This is kind of a hack, so I rewrote some of handsim in order not to rely on this subscriber.

values.description:
I generalized the Optitrack code so that it doesn't rely on the ground plane configuration, which saves the user some steps.

It uses the positions of the individual monitor markers to deduce the transformation between the Optitrack axes and Gazebo.

This pull request also renames the markers to be compatible with Emo's project file.

To test this pull request, use Motive with project file haptix_emo_edited.ttp.
values.title: Generalized Optitrack for different project files

summary.raw:
I generalized the Optitrack code so that it doesn't rely on the ground plane configuration, which saves the user some steps.

It uses the positions of the individual monitor markers to deduce the transformation between the Optitrack axes and Gazebo.

This pull request also renames the markers to be compatible with Emo's project file.

To test this pull request, use Motive with project file haptix_emo_edited.ttp.
summary.html:
I generalized the Optitrack code so that it doesn't rely on the ground plane configuration, which saves the user some steps.

It uses the positions of the individual monitor markers to deduce the transformation between the Optitrack axes and Gazebo.

This pull request also renames the markers to be compatible with Emo's project file.

To test this pull request, use Motive with project file haptix_emo_edited.ttp.

values.description:
~~Accompanies handsim-proprietary [PR#26](#!/osrf/handsim-proprietary/pull-request/26/added-collision-shapes-and-contact-sensors/diff).~~

~~Depends on a small fix to Gazebo in [PR#1413](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1413/allow-multiple-contact-sensors-per-link) which allows multiple contact sensors per link~~ contact sensor fix merged.

Changes the hand graphic and the contact sensor visualization graphics to visualize the new contact sensors. Also changed the sensor visualization to rectangles, not circles, added the ability to vary the sizes of the displayed contact areas, and enabled different transparency of contact areas that receive no contact.

![squarecontacts.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/rnoXja/images/1466788893-squarecontacts.png)
values.title: Changed contact sensor locations and image

summary.raw:
~~Accompanies handsim-proprietary [PR#26](#!/osrf/handsim-proprietary/pull-request/26/added-collision-shapes-and-contact-sensors/diff).~~

~~Depends on a small fix to Gazebo in [PR#1413](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1413/allow-multiple-contact-sensors-per-link) which allows multiple contact sensors per link~~ contact sensor fix merged.

Changes the hand graphic and the contact sensor visualization graphics to visualize the new contact sensors. Also changed the sensor visualization to rectangles, not circles, added the ability to vary the sizes of the displayed contact areas, and enabled different transparency of contact areas that receive no contact.

![squarecontacts.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/rnoXja/images/1466788893-squarecontacts.png)
summary.html:
Accompanies handsim-proprietary PR#26.

Depends on a small fix to Gazebo in PR#1413 which allows multiple contact sensors per link contact sensor fix merged.

Changes the hand graphic and the contact sensor visualization graphics to visualize the new contact sensors. Also changed the sensor visualization to rectangles, not circles, added the ability to vary the sizes of the displayed contact areas, and enabled different transparency of contact areas that receive no contact.

values.description:
This pull request creates a new executable on Windows `optitrackBridge` that uses NPTrackingTools.dll for getting the tracking information. Then, it sends the information over the network. I'm using the same multicast group and port than Motive but I created a new frameID.

The code is reused on Linux for unpacking the data coming from the "bridge" and for testing purposes.

On the Gazebo side, we can receive the tracking information from Motive or from the optritrackBridge.

I also fixed the compilation of the examples.
values.title: Optitrackbridge

summary.raw:
This pull request creates a new executable on Windows `optitrackBridge` that uses NPTrackingTools.dll for getting the tracking information. Then, it sends the information over the network. I'm using the same multicast group and port than Motive but I created a new frameID.

The code is reused on Linux for unpacking the data coming from the "bridge" and for testing purposes.

On the Gazebo side, we can receive the tracking information from Motive or from the optritrackBridge.

I also fixed the compilation of the examples.
summary.html:
This pull request creates a new executable on Windows optitrackBridge that uses NPTrackingTools.dll for getting the tracking information. Then, it sends the information over the network. I'm using the same multicast group and port than Motive but I created a new frameID.

The code is reused on Linux for unpacking the data coming from the "bridge" and for testing purposes.

On the Gazebo side, we can receive the tracking information from Motive or from the optritrackBridge.

I also fixed the compilation of the examples.

values.description:
This is a **temporary** fix that places a new MPL arm into the handsim repository. It references the STL meshes in gazebo_models and uses Nate's new collision shapes. It also integrates the MPL arm with HaptixControlPlugin, which means that arm and hand teleop work.

With this pull request, we can forget about packaging handsim-proprietary. However, we will need to replace this with a model that has correct inertias and better physics tuning in the future.
values.title: Integrated MPL arm with HaptixControlPlugin

summary.raw:
This is a **temporary** fix that places a new MPL arm into the handsim repository. It references the STL meshes in gazebo_models and uses Nate's new collision shapes. It also integrates the MPL arm with HaptixControlPlugin, which means that arm and hand teleop work.

With this pull request, we can forget about packaging handsim-proprietary. However, we will need to replace this with a model that has correct inertias and better physics tuning in the future.
summary.html:
This is a temporary fix that places a new MPL arm into the handsim repository. It references the STL meshes in gazebo_models and uses Nate's new collision shapes. It also integrates the MPL arm with HaptixControlPlugin, which means that arm and hand teleop work.

With this pull request, we can forget about packaging handsim-proprietary. However, we will need to replace this with a model that has correct inertias and better physics tuning in the future.

values.description:
As requested by pull request #54, I'm including the position of all individual markers in the message that the "bridge" generates.

I discovered a really interesting thing. If your motive configuration file has the streaming option enabled, when you call to TT_Update(), NPTrackingTools streams the data for you using the NatNet protocol (UDP multicast with the format that we already use). So, we don't need to create custom messages when using NPTrackingTools.dll .

I'm going to keep the OptiTrackBridge files for now because we have to do some latency tests but probably they will be removed in the future. We only need `windows/optitrackBridge.cc`.
values.title: Adding individual marker position to the optitrackBridge

summary.raw:
As requested by pull request #54, I'm including the position of all individual markers in the message that the "bridge" generates.

I discovered a really interesting thing. If your motive configuration file has the streaming option enabled, when you call to TT_Update(), NPTrackingTools streams the data for you using the NatNet protocol (UDP multicast with the format that we already use). So, we don't need to create custom messages when using NPTrackingTools.dll .

I'm going to keep the OptiTrackBridge files for now because we have to do some latency tests but probably they will be removed in the future. We only need `windows/optitrackBridge.cc`.
summary.html:
As requested by pull request #54, I'm including the position of all individual markers in the message that the "bridge" generates.

I discovered a really interesting thing. If your motive configuration file has the streaming option enabled, when you call to TT_Update(), NPTrackingTools streams the data for you using the NatNet protocol (UDP multicast with the format that we already use). So, we don't need to create custom messages when using NPTrackingTools.dll .

I'm going to keep the OptiTrackBridge files for now because we have to do some latency tests but probably they will be removed in the future. We only need windows/optitrackBridge.cc.

At long last, this adds a model to handsim that includes `mpl_right_forearm` from gazebo_models repo and adds on the HaptixControlPlugin SDF needed to make it work.

Contact sensors won't appear accurate unless [PR55](#!/osrf/handsim/pull-request/55/changed-contact-sensor-locations-and-image/diff) gets merged.

~~For best physics results, pair with [gazebo_models PR123](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-request/123/more-mpl-arm-updates/diff).~~ We are now copying the meshes and SDF from gazebo_models into handsim.
values.title: Add sanitized MPL arm to repo

summary.raw:
At long last, this adds a model to handsim that includes `mpl_right_forearm` from gazebo_models repo and adds on the HaptixControlPlugin SDF needed to make it work.

Contact sensors won't appear accurate unless [PR55](#!/osrf/handsim/pull-request/55/changed-contact-sensor-locations-and-image/diff) gets merged.

~~For best physics results, pair with [gazebo_models PR123](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-request/123/more-mpl-arm-updates/diff).~~ We are now copying the meshes and SDF from gazebo_models into handsim.
summary.html:
At long last, this adds a model to handsim that includes mpl_right_forearm from gazebo_models repo and adds on the HaptixControlPlugin SDF needed to make it work.

Contact sensors won't appear accurate unless PR55 gets merged.

For best physics results, pair with gazebo_models PR123. We are now copying the meshes and SDF from gazebo_models into handsim.

values.description:
This is meant to be a cheat-sheet style document that we distribute to teams. I'll place a downloadable copy on the web-page, and we might want to print/laminate a version for each team.

Additions and modifications are welcome.

To build:

1. Go into `doc` directory.
2. Run make
3. evince referenceguide.pdf

I didn't add this to the default cmake build system because I was lazy and didn't see a compelling need.
values.title: Added reference guide

values.description:
The IMU sensor frames should now match the following diagram:

![imu_frames.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/rnoXja/images/336919863-imu_frames.png)

The frames are shown as RGB corresponding to XYZ, with the X axis (red) pointing out from the finger/thumb nails, and the Z axis (blue) pointing out from the tip of the finger/thumb.

To test:

* Launch `gazebo worlds/arat.world`
* Open the `Topic Visualization` window (Ctrl+T)
* Select one of the imu topics (such as `/gazebo/default/mpl_haptix_right_forearm/index3/index3_imu_sensor/imu`)
* The values are pretty noisy, which makes them hard to read. It may be helpful to pause the simulation and step forward manually
* Gravity points down along the Z axis, so in the default configuration, this should correspond to a positive value along the X axis of the accelerometer for the fingers along the Y axis of the thumb. Verify this in the Topic viewer.
* Apply 11 Nm in the joint inspector widget to the `wristy` joint so that the thumb is pointing down. This should generate positive values along the Y axis of the fingers and a negative value along the Z axis of the thumb.
values.title: Rotate imu sensor frames to match diagram

summary.raw:
The IMU sensor frames should now match the following diagram:

![imu_frames.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/rnoXja/images/336919863-imu_frames.png)

The frames are shown as RGB corresponding to XYZ, with the X axis (red) pointing out from the finger/thumb nails, and the Z axis (blue) pointing out from the tip of the finger/thumb.

To test:

* Launch `gazebo worlds/arat.world`
* Open the `Topic Visualization` window (Ctrl+T)
* Select one of the imu topics (such as `/gazebo/default/mpl_haptix_right_forearm/index3/index3_imu_sensor/imu`)
* The values are pretty noisy, which makes them hard to read. It may be helpful to pause the simulation and step forward manually
* Gravity points down along the Z axis, so in the default configuration, this should correspond to a positive value along the X axis of the accelerometer for the fingers along the Y axis of the thumb. Verify this in the Topic viewer.
* Apply 11 Nm in the joint inspector widget to the `wristy` joint so that the thumb is pointing down. This should generate positive values along the Y axis of the fingers and a negative value along the Z axis of the thumb.
summary.html:
The IMU sensor frames should now match the following diagram:

The frames are shown as RGB corresponding to XYZ, with the X axis (red) pointing out from the finger/thumb nails, and the Z axis (blue) pointing out from the tip of the finger/thumb.

To test:

  • Launch gazebo worlds/arat.world
  • Open the Topic Visualization window (Ctrl+T)
  • Select one of the imu topics (such as /gazebo/default/mpl_haptix_right_forearm/index3/index3_imu_sensor/imu)
  • The values are pretty noisy, which makes them hard to read. It may be helpful to pause the simulation and step forward manually
  • Gravity points down along the Z axis, so in the default configuration, this should correspond to a positive value along the X axis of the accelerometer for the fingers along the Y axis of the thumb. Verify this in the Topic viewer.
  • Apply 11 Nm in the joint inspector widget to the wristy joint so that the thumb is pointing down. This should generate positive values along the Y axis of the fingers and a negative value along the Z axis of the thumb.

values.title: make joint stop softer

values.description:
The "Reset Mocap" button is now a label with three states:

- ON: Motion tracking is on
- PAUSED: Motion tracking was paused via spacebar
- NO DATA: no data was received from the optitrack

HaptixGUIPlugin tries continuously to start the service again if it the service is stopped. If no data was received from the optitrack (no objects found in scene), but the service thinks that it's on, we try to stop the service, to get it in a consistent state.

We also added the aforementioned publisher to Optitrack.cc that publishes if any objects were found in the scene.
values.title: Changed "Reset Mocap" button to a state indicator

summary.raw:
The "Reset Mocap" button is now a label with three states:

- ON: Motion tracking is on
- PAUSED: Motion tracking was paused via spacebar
- NO DATA: no data was received from the optitrack

HaptixGUIPlugin tries continuously to start the service again if it the service is stopped. If no data was received from the optitrack (no objects found in scene), but the service thinks that it's on, we try to stop the service, to get it in a consistent state.

We also added the aforementioned publisher to Optitrack.cc that publishes if any objects were found in the scene.
summary.html:
The "Reset Mocap" button is now a label with three states:

  • ON: Motion tracking is on
  • PAUSED: Motion tracking was paused via spacebar
  • NO DATA: no data was received from the optitrack

HaptixGUIPlugin tries continuously to start the service again if it the service is stopped. If no data was received from the optitrack (no objects found in scene), but the service thinks that it's on, we try to stop the service, to get it in a consistent state.

We also added the aforementioned publisher to Optitrack.cc that publishes if any objects were found in the scene.

values.title: reduce torque limits for fingers
update debug code and reduce torque further
values.reason: thumb reaction seems too slow, re-tuning pid

values.description:
Solution for issue #53. Optitrack viewpoint rotations are now disabled. Head motion tracking only induces translation in the user camera.

In order to get the rotations right, I had to add an offset between the camera position and the head marker position. Let me know if you'd like a longer explanation of these calculations.
values.title: Issue 53: Disable viewpoint rotations

summary.raw:
Solution for issue #53. Optitrack viewpoint rotations are now disabled. Head motion tracking only induces translation in the user camera.

In order to get the rotations right, I had to add an offset between the camera position and the head marker position. Let me know if you'd like a longer explanation of these calculations.
summary.html:
Solution for issue #53. Optitrack viewpoint rotations are now disabled. Head motion tracking only induces translation in the user camera.

In order to get the rotations right, I had to add an offset between the camera position and the head marker position. Let me know if you'd like a longer explanation of these calculations.

values.description:
#!/osrf/handsim/issue/61/enable-self-collision-for-hand

This is a proposed solution for Issue 61 that only enables `self_collide` on the fingertip links. I think that using model self_collide and bitmasks might be more complicated than is needed to create more realistic behavior for the hand.
values.title: Issue 61: Enabled self_collide on fingertips

summary.raw:
#!/osrf/handsim/issue/61/enable-self-collision-for-hand

This is a proposed solution for Issue 61 that only enables `self_collide` on the fingertip links. I think that using model self_collide and bitmasks might be more complicated than is needed to create more realistic behavior for the hand.
summary.html:
#!/osrf/handsim/issue/61/enable-self-collision-for-hand

This is a proposed solution for Issue 61 that only enables self_collide on the fingertip links. I think that using model self_collide and bitmasks might be more complicated than is needed to create more realistic behavior for the hand.
